description:
Harpagifer antarcticus is a species of small, benthic fish belonging to the family Harpagiferidae, which is endemic to the coastal waters of Antarctica. It is commonly known as the Antarctic spiny plunderfish or Antarctic plunderfish.

The Harpagifer antarcticus is a small, laterally compressed fish that typically measures around 10-15 centimeters in length. It has a large, protruding mouth with numerous small, sharp teeth, which it uses to feed on a variety of small crustaceans, mollusks, and other invertebrates. The fish's body is covered in small, bony plates or "scales" that provide protection from the harsh Antarctic environment.

This species is adapted to the cold, Antarctic waters, with a body temperature that is closely regulated to match the surrounding water temperature. It is capable of withstanding the freezing conditions of its habitat and can often be found in shallow, rocky areas along the Antarctic coastline.

Harpagifer antarcticus plays an important role in the Antarctic marine ecosystem, serving as a food source for larger predatory fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. The species is of particular interest to scientists studying the unique adaptations and resilience of organisms living in the extreme environments of the Antarctic region.
